hints.content: Let's try each set of stacks to see whether it equals $12$ plates.

###$10$ stacks of $2$ plates

![10 stacks of 2 plates](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/e236caf6ae252b7e4878874e24494b9ab86f2e17)

$2+2+2+2+2+2+2+2+2+2=20$

So Vicky *cannot* stack their $12$ plates this way.

###$8$ stacks of $4$ plates

![8 stacks of 4 plates](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/61fc82758935689a75573d3e99068b7eebacb76b)

$4+4+4+4+4+4+4+4=32$

So Vicky *cannot* stack their $12$ plates this way.

###$2$ stacks of $6$ plates

![2 stacks of 6 plates](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/2acc638135d60611bcc615db06a655a6e3233dee)

$6+6=12$ , so Vicky can stack their plates this way.

###$6$ stacks of $2$ plates

![6 stacks of 2 plates](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/11de40461574c26359055b1cc7b015c9311f15ff)

$2+2+2+2+2+2=12$ , so Vicky can stack their plates this way.

Vicky can stack their plates these ways:

- $2$ stacks of $6$ plates 
- $6$ stacks of $2$ plates

[[☃ explanation 1]]

question.content:
Vicky has $12$ plates.

**What are two ways Vicky can stack their plates?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This would be $20$ plates instead of $12$ plates.
This would be $32$ plates instead of $12$ plates.
